Line 36: Line 36:
=== Corruption ===
=== Corruption ===
â
Political corruption in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.{{clarify|date=January 2011}} This has led to the imprisonment of political figures and youth activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New Yorker]]|author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=http://www.trojkan.se|author=Kalla fakta}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian elections: independents fight for hearts and minds in 'fixed ballot'|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.
+
Political corruption in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref>. This has led to the imprisonment of political figures and youth activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New Yorker]]|author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=http://www.trojkan.se|author=Kalla fakta}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian elections: independents fight for hearts and minds in 'fixed ballot'|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts, with 10 being very clean and 0 being highly corrupt. Egypt ranked 98th out of the 178 countries included in the report.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results |title=CPI 2010 table |publisher=Transparency International |accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts, with 10 being very clean and 0 being highly corrupt. Egypt ranked 98th out of the 178 countries included in the report.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results |title=CPI 2010 table |publisher=Transparency International |accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
